GDSN definition: Party, which is authorized to view, use, download a set of Master Data provided by a Data Source.
Business name: Authorised Receiver of Product Information GLN (Global Location Number)
Business definition: The Global Location Number (GLN) that uniquely identifies the authorised receiver of the product information.
Example:
• Private label information directed to one specific buyer.
• Promotional information for a specific retailer.
• Product information shared with a solution provider for dissemination to multiple recipients.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to identify themselves within the GDSN network.
Used by the supplier to specifically provide a buyer with product data.

GDSN definition: An indicator identifying the trade item as the base unit level of the trade item hierarchy.
Business definition: The indicator that specifies this product does not contain another intended sellable unit.
Example:
• A case of bottled soda and the individual bottles of soda are both consumer units.  The case is not the base unit (Base Unit Indicator = “False”). The individual bottles are base units (Base Unit Indicator = “True”).
• Shampoo and conditioner as a combination pack where the combination pack is the base unit (Base Unit Indicator = “True”). The individual shampoo and conditioner are not base units and not available for sale individually from the combination pack.
• A jar of peanut butter and a jar of jelly wrapped together as a combination pack where the combination pack is not the base unit (Base Unit Indicator = “False”) but the individual jars are the base units (Base Unit Indicator = “True”).
• A case of chicken for food service where the individual chickens do not have GTINs. The case is the base unit (Base Unit Indicator = “True”).
• A box of cereal – the box is the base unit (Base Unit Indicator = “True”).
Usage Statement: Used to manage internal order/sell unit relationships and integration in conjunction with Consumer Unit Indicator.

GDSN definition: Identifies whether the trade item to be taken possession of ,or to be consumed or used by an end user or both, as determined by the manufacturer.  The end user could be, but is not limited to, a consumer as in items sold at retail, or a patient/clinician/technician in a healthcare setting, or an operator for foodservice such as restaurants, airlines, cafeterias, etc.
Business definition: The indicator that specifies the product can be purchased or, in some trade channels (e.g., food service, healthcare), used by, the consumer.
Example:
• Container of guacamole
• Carton of nutrition bars
• Nutrition bar each
• Single portion packet of ketchup (used in food service) with no barcode
• Image showing a digital movie
• Image showing a multi-beverage pack
Usage Statement: Used to manage internal order/sell item relationships and integration in conjunction with Base Unit Indicator.

GDSN definition: An indicator identifying that the information provider considers the trade item as a despatch (shipping) unit. This may be relationship dependent based on channel of trade or other point to point agreement.
Business definition: The indicator identifying that the information provider considers the trade item as a shipping unit.
Example:
• Image of a case of a product
• Image of a pallet of product
Usage Statement: Used to indicate that a product can be shipped in conjunction with Orderable Unit Indicator.

GDSN definition: An indicator identifying that the information provider considers this trade item to be at a hierarchy level where they will accept orders from customers. This may be different from what the information provider identifies as a despatch unit. This may be a relationship dependent based on channel of trade or other point to point agreement
Business definition: The indicator that specifies the product can be ordered.
Example:
• Image of a 15 pound bag of dog food with consumer unit = yes and orderable = yes
• Image of jar of jelly with consumer unit = yes and orderable = no
• Image of a case of jars of jelly with consumer unit = yes and orderable = yes
Usage Statement: Used to indicate that a product is orderable.

GDSN definition: Describes the hierarchical level of the trade item. The attribute tradeItemUnitDescriptorCode is mandatory. Examples: "CASE", ”PALLET”.
Business definition: The code that describes the product's packaging level.
Example: Show images of a product at multiple levels of the hierarchy, such as each, pack, case, pallet.
Usage Statement: Used to communicate how the product hierarchy is constructed.

GDSN definition: A particular Global trade item Number, a numerical value used to uniquely identify a trade item. A trade item is any trade item (trade item or service) upon which there is a need to retrieve pre-defined information and that may be planned, priced, ordered, delivered and or invoiced at any point in any supply chain.
Business definition: The global number that uniquely identifies a product and its various packaging levels (e.g. item, case, pallet) physical or non-physical.
Example:
• Image of bottle of water with a highlight on the barcode number. Image of a case of a product with a highlight on the barcode number.
• Image of a case of a product (as the first image) but then in a case and with a different GTIN on the case.
Usage Statement: Used for any product or service ordered, invoiced, shipped, or sold in store or online. Often represented as a barcode on the product.

GDSN definition: Alternative means to the Global Trade Item Number to identify a trade item.
Business definition: An identifier, other than the GTIN, which provides an additional identification for the product.
Example:
• Image of a medical product with a GTIN and approval number highlighted. 
• Image of a packaged food good price list showing brand owner’s internal item code.
• Image of a laser printer with a model number on the package.
Usage Statement: Used for additional product identification that allows a buyer to identify a product by other identification systems.  Used in conjunction with Additional Product Identification Type Code

GDSN definition: This code will be used to cross-reference the Vendors internal trade item number to the GTIN in a one to one relationship.
Business definition: The code indicating the type of Additional Product Identification used.
Example:
• Image of a medical product with a GTIN and approval number highlighted. 
• Image of a laser printer with a model number on the package.
• Image of a packaged food good price list showing brand owner’s internal item code.
• We should have the type code and the value along with the image of the additional identifier.

Use in conjunction with Additional Product Identification.
Usage Statement: Used to declare the type of the additional product identification that allows a buyer to know which identification system is used.

GDSN definition: Date on which the information of the master data is valid for order to pay.
Business definition: The date/time when the product information becomes effective.
Example:
The seller is making a minor change in compliance with the GS1 GTIN Management Standard (https://www.gs1.org/sites/default/files/docs/barcodes/GS1_GTIN_Management_Standard.pdf), such as package markings or a new accreditation label, and wants to inform buyer of the date/time the change will be begin.

Note:  In some instances, this value could be generated by a system.
Usage Statement: Used by the data recipient to determine the date/time when the product information should be applied in their system.

GDSN definition: A code determining the type of display a trade item is, for example Shelf Display Ready Packaging.

Example:
• Images and codes of candy in a shelf-ready display
• Battery shipper
• Shelf display ready packaging

GDSN definition: An indicator whether or not a trade item is or could be used as a display unit. A display unit is intended to be shipped to a store without being split at a distribution centre or similar party and is intended to be displayed in a retail store either on a shelf or on the shop floor.
Business definition: The indicator that specifies a trade item can be used as a display.
Example:

Used by the buyer for promotional planning and logistics
Used for shelf planning and reduces stocking time.

GDSN definition: Code specifying a product category according to the GS1 Global Product Classification (GPC) standard.
Business definition: The code used to group products based on similar characteristics according to the GS1 Global Product Classification (GPC).
Example: An image that highlights three different products in the same GPC with the GPC code and description (no attributes, just the GPC brick).
Usage Statement: Used for multiple use cases such as data quality, category management, space management and workflow routing.

GDSN definition: Code specifying the type of the Global Product Classification (GPC) attribute, for example 20000081 - Grape Variety.
Business name: Global Product Category Attribute Type Code
Business definition: The code identifying the attribute of a particular product category from GS1 Global Product Classification (GPC).
Example: 20000081 - Grape Variety
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to offer advanced filtering options for consumers shopping online.

May be used by the buyer in assortment planning.

Used in conjunction with the Global Product Category Attribute Value Code.

GDSN definition: The GS1 provided code which identifies the Global Product Classification Attribute Value.

Example: CHARDONNAY
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to offer advanced filtering options for consumers shopping online.

May be used by the buyer in assortment planning.

Used in conjunction with the Global Product Category Attribute Type Code.

• a case of single product

GDSN definition: This represents the Total quantity of next lower level trade items that this trade item contains.

Example:
• Quantity tab
• a multi-pack
• a case of single product
• a pallet of cases of a single product
• a pallet of different products (different cases)
Usage Statement: Used by a buyer and/or consumer to understand what type of product they are receiving; also used for inventory/warehouse management.

GDSN definition: The number of one child trade item (as identified by the association of ChildTradeItem class to TradeItemIdentification class) contained by the parent trade item. The child trade item must be in the hierarchy level immediately below the parent trade item.
Business definition: The count of each specific product within this item.
Example:
• Quantity tab
• a multi-pack
• a case of single product
• a pallet of cases of a single product
• a pallet of different products (different cases)
Usage Statement: Used by a buyer and/or consumer to understand what type of product they are receiving; also used for inventory/warehouse management.

GDSN definition: A particular Global trade item Number, a numerical value used to uniquely identify a trade item. • a multi-pack

GDSN definition: A code identifying nutrients contained in the animal food or nutrition product.
Business definition: The code that represents the nutrient or energy element that is found in the product.
Example: Show image of nutrition fact panel side by side with nutrient code for each line.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer and the buyer of the nutrient or energy element that is found in the product.

Business definition: The amount of the nutrient or energy element contained in the product as a percentage of Feeding Amount.
Example: Image of product where the nutrient and the percentage are highlighted.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the nutrient or energy element as a percentage of Feeding Amount.

GDSN definition: Minimum guaranteed percentage of the specified nutrient contained in the trade item.
Business definition: The highest amount of the nutrient or energy element that the product may contain as a percentage of Feeding Amount.
Example: Image of product where the nutrient and the percentage are highlighted.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the nutrient or energy element as a percentage of Feeding Amount.

GDSN definition: Minimum guaranteed percentage of the specified nutrient contained in the trade item.
Business definition: The lowest amount of the nutrient or energy element that the product may contain as a percentage of Feeding Amount.
Example: Image of product where the nutrient and the percentage are highlighted.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the nutrient or energy element as a percentage of Feeding Amount.

GDSN definition: Measurement value indicating the amount of the nutrient contained in the animal food or nutrition product. It is expressed relative to the animal nutrient quantity contained basis measurement.  For example, 3 grams in the case of 3 grams per 12 kilogram.  Allows for the representation of the same value in different units of measure but not multiple values.

Example: Image of product where the nutrient and the quantity are highlighted.

GDSN definition: It is a measure of Ultra Violet B (UVB) radiation protection and ranges from 1 to 90.
Business definition: The rating of how well a product will protect the skin from UV rays.
Usage Statement: Used to notify the buyer and consumer of the SPF ratings to group similar products and for consumer purchasing decisions.

GDSN definition: Percentage of alcohol contained in the base unit trade item.
Business definition: The percentage of alcohol by volume contained in the product.
Example:
Packaging or label that shows the percentage of alcohol.
Beer shows %ABV (alcohol by volume).

Used to communicate to the buyer and the consumer the percentage of alcohol by volume contained in the product.
Based on the %alcohol, the buyer can make an informed decision if the product can be sold in-store.
Alcohol percentage may be used to calculate tax.

GDSN definition: The year in which the majority of ingredients are harvested and/or the alcoholic beverage is produced. Determination as to whether the vintage year is the harvest date or production date is according to requirements in the Target Market.

Example:
• Show an example of a listing for a preliminary product, where the allergens are not yet confirmed.

Usage Statement: Used by the seller to confirm to the buyer that all relevant allergen information is complete.

GDSN definition: Code indicating the type of allergen.
Business definition: The code to indicate a specific allergen.
Example: Image of the allergen code list with various allergens ticked.

Example: Image of three different products with the following statements appearing on each one: Contains NUTS, May contain NUTS.

GDSN definition: Free text field for any additional nutritional claims in relations to animal feed.

Example:
• Natural pre-biotic helps support healthy digestion
• High levels of clinically proven antioxidants to support immune system and offset oxidative stress
• High levels of high quality and highly digestible protein and fat to meet increased energy needs
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to inform the consumer about the product’s health and/or nutritional claims in order to assist the consumer in making an informed purchasing decision.

Usage Statement:
Used by the consumer to understand the life stage of the animal for the specified feeding amount within the animal’s life stage.
Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The highest weight (in a weight range) of the animal to be fed by the trade item.  This value qualifies the quantity of feed for the feed life-stage.
Business name: Maximum Weight Of Animal Being Fed
Business definition: The highest weight of the animal intended to be fed the product as defined by the manufacturer.
Example:
Image of feeding weight table from a package of pet food.

See dog and kitten feeding chart examples.
Usage Statement: Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The lowest weight (in a weight range) of the animal to be fed by the trade item.  This value qualifies the quantity of feed for the feed lifestage.
Business name: Minimum Weight Of Animal Being Fed
Business definition: The lowest weight of the animal intended to be fed the product as defined by the manufacturer.
Example:
Image of feeding weight table from a package of pet food.

See dog and kitten feeding chart examples.
Usage Statement: Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The amount of feed which is specified for the feed life-stage and qualified by the weight of animal being fed.
Business definition: The amount of feed (with its unit of measure) that is specified on the product label. This may be associated with the feed life-stage and qualified by the weight of the animal being fed.
Example:
Image of feeding weight table that also includes an exact feeding amount from a package of pet food.

See horse and pony feeding chart example.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the correct amount of the product to feed the animal.

GDSN definition: The maximum amount of feed which is specified for the feed life-stage and qualified by the weight of animal being fed.
Business definition: The largest amount of product (with its unit of measure) specified for the animal being fed as defined by the manufacturer.
Example:
Image of feeding weight table that also includes the feeding amount from a package of pet food.

See dog and kitten feeding chart examples.
Usage Statement:
Used to inform the consumer of the maximum amount of the product to feed the animal.

Used in conjunction with Minimum Feeding Amount if a range is being specified. If a single amount is to be specified, use Feeding Amount, instead.

GDSN definition: The minimum amount of feed which is specified for the feed life-stage and qualified by the weight of animal being fed.
Business definition: The least amount of product (with its unit of measure) specified for the animal being fed as defined by the manufacturer.
Example:
Image of feeding weight table that also includes the feeding amount from a package of pet food.

See dog and kitten feeding chart examples.
Usage Statement:
Used to inform the consumer of the minimum amount of the product to feed the animal.

Used in conjunction with Maximum Feeding Amount if a range is being specified. If a single amount is to be specified, use Feeding Amount, instead.

GDSN definition: How frequently it is recommended to feed an animal the quantity of feed within a time period for the specified feed life-stage. Examples: 2 feedings per day,  maximum 2 chew sticks  and/or 2 portions per day.
Business definition: The recommended frequency to feed an animal the quantity of feed within a time period for the specified feed life-stage.
Example:
• daily
• twice daily
• maximum 2 chew sticks
• 3 portions per day
Usage Statement:
Used to inform consumers of the time period in which and/or how often the animal is recommended to be fed with the specified feeding amount.

Used in conjunction with: Animal Feed Target Life Stage, Feeding Amount, Minimum Feeding Amount, Maximum Feeding Amount, Minimum Weight of Animal Being Fed, Maximum Weight of Animal Being Fed, Feeding Instructions.

GDSN definition: Indicates if batteries are either included or not included with the trade item.
Business definition: The indicator specifying whether batteries are included with the product.
Example:
• Image of a smartphone with non-removable battery.
• Image of a toy with removable batteries.
• Image of an electric toothbrush.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform the consumer whether batteries are included with the product. Online retailer can suggest battery purchase. Used to flag waste or shipping restrictions.

GDSN definition: Indicates if batteries are required to operate the trade item.
Business definition: The indicator specifying whether batteries are required to operate the product, including built in batteries and removable batteries.
Example:
• Image of a toy that requires two batteries.
• Image of a toy that requires four batteries.
• A product with a rechargeable battery in it. Flashlight, electric toothbrush with a fixed battery that can be recharged.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform the consumer whether batteries are required to operate the product.  Used in conjunction with Batteries Included Indicator, Number of Batteries Required, Batteries Built In Indicator, and Number of Batteries Built In.

GDSN definition: This code is defined as an indicator whether or not any batteries included with the trade item are built into the trade item during manufacturing. and cannot be changed or removed.
Business definition: The indicator specifying whether batteries are built into the product.
Example:
• Image of a toy that requires two batteries. (no)
• Image of a toy that requires four batteries. (no) 
• A product with a rechargeable battery in it. Electric toothbrush with a fixed battery that can be recharged. (yes)
• A Bluetooth GPS finder with a built in battery (e.g. TILE). (yes)
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform the consumer if batteries are built into the product. Used to highlight waste, storage or shipping restrictions.

GDSN definition: The type of battery family (e.g. Lithium, NiMH) of batteries used by the product.
Business definition: The code which indicates the material of the battery.
Example: Image of several battery types showing the waste restrictions. For example, battery material of Lithium or NiMH. Example: electric toothbrush
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform the consumer of the battery material for proper handling. Used to highlight waste, storage or shipping restrictions.

GDSN definition: Type of battery required to operate the game. If “Are Batteries Required” or if “Quantity of Batteries" is populated or if "Are Batteries Included = “Yes” this attribute is required.
Business definition: The code which indicates the physical size/shape of the battery used to operate the product.
Example: Image of different sized batteries (i.e. AA, AAA) including the product that the batteries are used for, alongside the code list. Example:  toothbrush, battery packs of different sizes, watch, flashlight
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform the consumer of the size of the battery needed for the product. Often used in conjunction with Battery Material Type Code.

GDSN definition: The weight of each battery included with or built into the trade item.
Business definition: The weight of one battery included with or built into the product.
Example: Image of different sized batteries (i.e. AA, AAA) including the product that the batteries are used for, alongside the battery weight. Example:  toothbrush, watch, flashlight,
Usage Statement: Used to declare the battery weights for disposal.

GDSN definition: The quantity of batteries built into the trade item during manufacturing. This includes batteries that can or cannot be changed or removed.
Business definition: The number of batteries built into the product.
Example:
• A product with two rechargeable batteries in it:  two batteries.
• Electric toothbrush with a fixed battery that can be recharged: one battery.
• A Bluetooth GPS finder with a built in battery (e.g. TILE):  one battery.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform the consumer of the number of batteries built into the product. Used to highlight waste, storage or shipping restrictions.

GDSN definition: The number of batteries required to operate the trade item.
Business definition: The number of batteries required to operate the product.
Example:
• Image of a toy that requires two batteries.
• Image of a toy that requires four batteries.
• A product with a rechargeable battery in it. Flashlight, electric toothbrush with a fixed battery that can be recharged.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to inform consumer of the number of removable or reusable batteries to operate the product.

GDSN definition: ﻿The name of the certification standard or the type of certification, e.g. product, process, company, packaging or conformity.
Business definition: The name of the certification standard or the type of certification, e.g. product, process, company, packaging or conformity.
Example:
The following example illustrates the use of certification attributes commonly used together for a product with an FSC certification:
- Certification Standard = Packaging
- certificationIdentification = FOREST_STEWARDSHIP_COUNCIL_MIX
- Certification Statement On Package = FSC Mix percentage of at least 70%
- Certification Value = FSC_C117990
- Subject of Certification Description = Packaging from responsible sources
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate either the standard the certification is based upon or the type of certification that was performed.

GDSN definition: ﻿The unique identification (ID) that provides a trade item's certification standard value, official licensing number or identification which proves that a product/process has passed the certification procedure.
Business definition: The unique identification (ID) that provides a trade item's certification standard value, official licensing number or identification which proves that a product/process has passed the certification procedure.
Example:
The following example illustrates the use of certification attributes commonly used together for a product with an FSC certification:
- Certification Standard = Packaging
- certificationIdentification = FOREST_STEWARDSHIP_COUNCIL_MIX
- Certification Statement On Package = FSC Mix percentage of at least 70%
- Certification Value = FSC_C117990
- Subject of Certification Description = Packaging from responsible sources
Usage Statement: Used by buyers and consumers to verify the authenticity of a certificate.

GDSN definition: Expresses in text the consumer storage instructions of a product which are normally held on the label or accompanying the product. This information may or may not be labeled on the pack. Instructions may refer to a suggested storage temperature, a specific storage requirement.
Business definition: The instructions and information provided to the consumer about proper storage for the product.
Example:
• Refrigerate after opening
• Keep out of direct sunlight
Usage Statement: Used to provide instructions and information to the consumer about the proper storage of the product for safety, quality, or taste.

GDSN definition: Expresses in text the consumer usage instructions of a product which are normally held on the label or accompanying the product. This information may or may not be labeled on the pack. Instructions may refer to a the how the consumer is to use the product, This does not include storage, food preparations, and drug dosage and preparation instructions.
Business definition: The instructions and information provided to the consumer on the usage of the product.
Example:
• For cleansing products: wash face and apply to skin
• For food: best served chilled
Usage Statement: Used to provide instructions and information to the consumer about the recommended use of the product. May be used to provide serving suggestions for food.

GDSN definition: The instructions on how to assemble the trade item.
Business definition: The instructions on how to assemble the product for final consumer usage.
Example: Text instructions on how to assemble a product.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer's customer service to answer questions about product assembly and to assemble the product for the consumer.
Used by the consumer to assemble the product.

GDSN definition: The percentage of fat contained in milk content of the product.
Business name: Percent of Milk Fat In Dairy
Business definition: The percentage of milk fat contained in the milk portion of the dairy product.
Example:
Image of:
• different sized milk containers showing the percent of milk fat in each.
• yogurt container showing the percent of milk fat.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer for assortment planning.

Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The indication whether or not the milk used was actively homogenised. The homogenisation of milk is a technical process in the dairy. The milk fat is milled to such an extent that further creaming is prevented.
Business definition: The indicator specifying whether or not the milk used is homogenised. The homogenisation of milk is a technical process in the dairy business. The milk fat is milled to such an extent that further creaming is prevented.
Example: Image of a milk container showing that it is homogenised on the package.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer for assortment planning.

Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The amount of fat contained in the base product expressed in percentage
Business definition: The percentage of fat in the dry matter of a cheese product. Dry matter is the content of a product after all fluids are removed.
Example: Image of a cheese product showing the percentage of fat.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer for assortment planning.

Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The scientific name associated with the speciesforFisheryStatisticsPurposesCode.
Business definition: The scientific name of fish and seafood products.
Example: Scientific name for Atlantic cod is Gadus morhua.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the scientific name of the fish and seafood (in EU legally required).

Used for reporting to authorities.

GDSN definition: The code indicating what type of fishing gear was used to catch fish and seafood.
Business definition: The code indicating what type of fishing gear was used to catch fish and seafood.
Example:
Legally required codes:
• Code 04 for Dredges
• Code 08 for Traps

Additional voluntary codes:
• Code DRB for Boat dredges
• Code DRH for Hand dredges
• GILLNETS_PELAGIC for Gillnets: Set (anchored) gillnets: pelagic gillnets
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the gear used to catch fish and seafood (in EU legally required). Codes specified by FAO (Fisheries and Aquaculture Department of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations) and WWF (World Wide Fund For Nature) are accepted designations for wild catch fishing gear.

Used for reporting to authorities.

GDSN definition: The code indicating how the fish and seafood were grown and harvested or caught.
Business definition: The code indicating how the fish and seafood were grown and harvested or caught.
Example:
• AQUACULTURE
• INLAND_FISHERY
• MARINE_FISHERY

Additional voluntary code:
• AQUACULTURE_PONDS_EXTENSIVE for Aquaculture ponds - extensive production
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the production method of fish and seafood (in EU legally required), as well as the aquaculture production system beyond the legally required information. Codes specified by FAO (Fisheries and Aquaculture Department of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations) and WWF (World Wide Fund For Nature) are accepted designations for fish and seafood production methods and aquaculture production systems.

Used for reporting to authorities.

GDSN definition: A code depicting that the referred product was previously frozen or not.
Business definition: The code indicating whether the fish was previously frozen or not.
Example: Code value PREVIOUSLY_FROZEN with an image of a thawed fish including a label that indicates the fish was previously frozen.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer and the consumer to know whether fish can be re-frozen after purchase.

GDSN definition: A visible number indicating the specific risk and thus the required precautions associated with a dangerous or hazardous good for example, the indication of the hazardous label number according to chapter 3.2, table A of the ADR.
Business definition: The visible number indicating the specific risk and precaution associated with dangerous goods.
Example:
2.1 Flammable gases
2.2 Non flammable, non-toxic gases
Usage Statement: Used to communicate the visible number(s) on the transport vehicle that specify the risks to health, safety, property or the environment. Used in conjunction with the  Hazardous Label Sequence Number.

GDSN definition: A sequence number indicating the primacy of one dangerous/hazardous label number over another. For example, a value of 1 would indicate that the associated hazard label number is the primary, 2 = secondary, etc.
Business definition: The sequence number indicating the level of danger represented by the Hazardous Label Number.
Example: A value of 1 would indicate that the associated hazard label number is the primary danger, 2 = secondary danger, etc.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to describe to the buyer the level and order of dangerous/hazardous label number for the purpose of transporting. Used in conjunction with the Hazardous Label Number.

GDSN definition: The first date/time that the buyer is allowed to sell the trade item to consumers. Usually related to a specific geography. ISO 8601 date format CCYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.
Business definition: The date/time when the product can first be sold to or ordered by the consumer.
Example:
•  A cell phone manufacturer sets the date/time for the sale of a new cell phone to the public.  This date/time is the Consumer Sell Date and is when retailers can publish details about the phone on their website and begin to take orders.  The phone is not available for delivery or physical pick-up until a later date/time, which is the Consumer Restricted Delivery Date/Time.
•  A seller is releasing a new potato chip and the seller has a promotional announcement to the public introducing the product on the same day the product is available for purchase by the consumer.  In this scenario, there is no Consumer Restricted Delivery Date/Time.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer when a product can first be sold to or ordered by the consumer. If there is not a Consumer Restricted Delivery Date/Time, this is also the date when the consumer can take physical possession of the product.

GDSN definition: The date from which the trade item is no longer available from the information provider, including seasonal or temporary trade item and services.
Business definition: The date/time when the product is no longer available for order from the seller.
Example:
• Christmas ornament is no longer available to be ordered as of 12-December-2035.
• Wine vintage 1925 is no longer available to be ordered as of 02-May-2019.
• A bonus toothpaste item with a GTIN different from the base item is no longer available to be ordered as of 16-April-2020.
• The brand owner has discontinued Sour Cream and Onion chips. The End Availability Date is 01-Nov-2035.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer when a product is no longer available for order, including seasonal trade items. Enables the buyer to manage item life cycle processes.

GDSN definition: Indicates the earliest date that an order can be placed for the trade item.
Business definition: The earliest date/time an order will be processed for the product.
Example: Orders placed for lamb and rice adult dog food will not be processed before 01-September-2022.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer when orders for a product will first be processed.

GDSN definition: Indicates the earliest date that the trade item can be shipped. This is independent of any specific ship-from location.
Business definition: The date/time the product is first available to ship from the seller or the service is available. Link to First Ship Date/Time.
Example: Skin care lotion is first available to ship on 01-Nov-2035.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer when the product is first available to ship or the service is available to begin.

GDSN definition: Represent an agreed to minimum quantity of the trade item that can be ordered. A number or a count. This applies to each individual order. Can be a fixed amount for all customers in a target market.
Business definition: The minimum quantity of the product required on a single order by the seller.
Example:
Vendor A has a minimum order requirement of 200 for Item A.

Minimum order quantity could be one pallet or one pallet layer or one master carton or one tray.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller and the buyer to ensure that the orders are at sufficient enough level to meet shipping and processing requirements.

GDSN definition: The date (CCYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS) from which the trade item becomes available from the supplier, including seasonalor temporary trade item and services.
Business definition: The date/time the product is first available to ship from the seller or the service is available.
Example: Skin care lotion is first available to ship on 01-Nov-2035.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer when the product is first available to ship or the service is available to begin.

GDSN definition: The first date/time that the buyer is allowed to deliver or ship the trade item to consumers. Usually related to a specific geography.
Business definition: The date/time when the consumer can first take physical possession of the product when there is a restriction imposed by the seller.
Example:
•  A cell phone manufacturer sets the date/time for the sale of a new cell phone to the public.  This date/time is the Consumer Sell Date and is when retailers can publish details about the phone on their website and begin to take orders.  The phone is not available for delivery or physical pick-up until a later date/time, which is the Consumer Restricted Delivery Date/Time.
•  A seller is releasing a new potato chip and the seller has a promotional announcement to the public introducing the product on the same day the product is available for purchase by the consumer.  In this scenario, there is no Consumer Restricted Delivery Date/Time.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer the date/time when the consumer can physically take possession of the product. Online: the buyer ships the product to the consumer and the consumer would expect to receive the product on this date or after. Physical:  the date the consumer could visit a physical site and take possession of the product.

GDSN definition: Code indicating the diet the product is suitable for.
Business definition: The code indicating the diet the product is suitable for.
Example: Images of product labels marked with diet types such as Vegan, Halal, Vegetarian
Usage Statement:
Used by the seller to notify buyers and consumers about the dietary regime that a product may belong to.  This is not an indication of certification and may not appear on the physical product.  It could also be used to market specific products based on dietary regime.

Used by institutions or food service when creating meals, ensuring that the product complies with a dietary regime.

GDSN definition: Identification of the type of duty or tax or fee applicable to the trade item. This will vary by target market.
Business definition: The code identifying a specific type of tax, levy, duty or fee associated with the type of product or service.
Example: VAT, Packaging/Recycling Tax, Alcohol Tax
Usage Statement:
Used to communicate the type of tax, levy, duty or fee applied to the product.
Used to identify the portion of the invoice that is tax.
Used to communicate to the buyer the amount of levy, duty or fee that they will need to pay.
This is a local code list. https://www.gs1.org/standards/gdsn/3-x

GDSN definition: A description of tax type for example "Taxes sure les supports audio".
Business definition: The description of the code that identifies a specific type of tax, levy, duty or fee associated with the type of product or service.
Example:
• VAT
• Packaging/Recycling Tax
• Alcohol Tax
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to understand the meaning of the Tax Type Code.

GDSN definition: Depicts the applicability of the tax rate or amount for a trade item for example zero, low or exempt.
Business definition: The code representing the level of tax rate applied by a government to the product.
Example:
• STANDARD
• LOW
• ZERO
• EXEMPT
Usage Statement: Used to communicate to the buyer the type of rates for taxes or levies applied to a product or service.

GDSN definition: The current tax or duty rate percentage applicable to the trade item.
Business definition: The percentage of tax, levy, duty or fee associated to the type of product.
Example: Show an electronics product with its associated Tax Type Code and Tax Percentage
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to identify the correct tax percentage applicable to the product.

Used in conjunction with Tax Type Code.

GDSN definition: A Governing body that creates and maintains standards related to organic products.
Business definition: The governing body that creates and maintains standards related to organic products and/or certifies products as organic.
Example:
An image of a strawberry jam labelled as organic.
Show that the attribute value sent to the buyer is:
Code value 6 (which represents USDA - US Department of Agriculture)

An image of a box of cereal labelled as organic.
Show that the attribute value sent to the buyer is:
Code value 13 (which represents Biopark - organic farmers association located in the north of Germany)
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer for verification purposes.

GDSN definition: Used to indicate the organic status of a trade item or of one or more of its components.
Business definition: The code indicating the organic content of the product.
Example:
• An image of a container of juice, with a code value of 1, and the image depicts "100% organic".
• An image of a dog treat, transmitted with code value of 5, and depicts that code value 5 translates to "Not Organic".
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to enable search and discovery for the consumer. Used by the buyer for space and assortment planning.

GDSN definition: A statement of the presence or absence of genetically modified protein or DNA.
Business definition: The code indicating the presence or absence of genetically modified protein or DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) in the product.
Example: Image of a bottle of milk and the code indicating "FREE_FROM"
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the GMO (Genetically Modified Organism) declaration of the product.  Used by the buyer in assortment planning.

GDSN definition: Note: This attribute is being deprecated in a future release. Use growingMethodCode in GrowingMethodInformation class in the same module.  The code indicating how the product has been grown, cultivated, reared and/or raised.
Business definition: The code indicating how the product has been grown, cultivated, reared and/or raised.
Example:
• Carton of eggs with Growing Method Code = CAGE_FREE, indicating the eggs come from a chicken able to move about inside a barn without being confined to cages.
• Package of chicken with Growing Method Code = FREE_RANGE, indicating it comes from a chicken able to access an outdoor area.
• Box of cut flowers with Growing Method Code = COCONUT_HUSK, indicating the flowers are grown in coconut husk chips.
• Tray of tomatoes with Growing Method Code = SUNLIGHT, indicating the plants are grown using natural sunlight (i.e., the solar radiation that is visible at Earth’s surface).
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the growing method of the product. Used by the buyer in assortment planning.

Not used for fish and seafood in EU, rather please reference Fish Production Method Code.

GDSN definition: Information on the constituent ingredient make-up of the product as specified.
Business definition: The composition of the product that matches what appears on the package.
Example: Full ingredient list for food which appears as it does on the product package.
Usage Statement: Used to indicate to the consumer the composition of the product that may include allergens and contaminations.

GDSN definition: The fruit juice content of the trade item expressed as a percentage.
Business name: Percent of Fruit and/or Vegetable Juice
Business definition: The amount of fruit and/or vegetable juice contained in the product, expressed as a percentage of the total volume.
Example:
• For a bottle of fruit juice showing the product contains 100% juice on the package:
Percent of Fruit and/or Vegetable Juice = 100

• For a frozen novelty bar showing the product contains 65% juice on the package:
Percent of Fruit and/or Vegetable Juice = 65
 
• For a container of mixed organic carrot and apple juices showing the product contains 83% juice on the package:
Percent of Fruit and/or Vegetable Juice = 83
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer for assortment planning.
Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: The name of any additive or genetic modification contained or not contained in the trade item.
Business definition: The name of an additive that is or may be contained in the product.
Example:
Image of a product showing the additive "Natural Flavouring" on the package.

Provide an example of a product containing multiple additives.
Usage Statement:
Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

Used in conjunction with Additive Containment Code. May also be used with additiveTypeCodeReference (GDD name).

GDSN definition: Code indicating the level of presence of the additive.
Business definition: The code to indicate the precision of an additive in the product.
Example:
An image of a product containing an additive(s) 
•  Contains
Usage Statement:
Used to communicate to the consumer and the buyer the additive containment status.

Used in conjunction with Additive Name. May also be used with additiveTypeCodeReference (GDD name).

GDSN definition: The vine variety used for the production of this wine for example Merlot expressed as a code.
Business definition: The code indicating the grape variety used to produce this wine. Please refer to any local regulation requirements.
Example:
• MERLOT
• SAUVIGNON_BLANC
• SHIRAZ
Usage Statement:
Used by the consumer for search and discovery.

Used by restaurants/menu planners for pairing alcohol with food.

Used by the buyer for assortment planning and shelf placement.

GDSN definition: Text field indicating one ingredient or ingredient group (according to regulations of the target market). Ingredients include any additives (colorings, preservatives, e-numbers, etc) that are encompassed.
Business definition: A single ingredient or a complex ingredient that is taken from the Ingredient Statement.
Example: * See sample ingredient list images in separate tab
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer, in conjunction with the Ingredient Sequence on Package, to digitally recreate the list of ingredients in the correct sequence.

GDSN definition: Incremental value (01, 02, 03…) indicating the ingredient order by content percentage of the product. (major ingredient = 01, second ingredient =01.01) etc..
Business definition: The incremental value (01, 02, 03…) indicating the order of ingredients listed on the package.
Example: * See sample ingredient list images in separate tab
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to digitally recreate the list of ingredients in the correct sequence.

GDSN definition: The code specifying the preparation methods the manufacturer has used on the product during the manufacturing process.
Business definition: The code specifying the preparation methods the manufacturer has used on the product during the manufacturing process.
Example:
• A fish product that is breaded and sold in a frozen state by the manufacturer: Manufacturer Preparation Type Code = BREAD, FREEZE

• A meat product (e.g., deli meats for sandwiches) that is cut into thin, flat pieces by the manufacturer from a larger portion: Manufacturer Preparation Type Code = SLICE
Usage Statement:
Used by buyers for assortment planning.
Used by buyers to enable search and discovery by consumers in e-commerce and online stores.
Used by consumers to determine their product preference and enable comparative shopping decisions.

GDSN definition: The total number of servings contained in the package.
Business definition: The total number of servings contained in the product as shown on the product package.
Example: Image of a box of cereal highlighting the number of servings contained in the box.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the number of servings.  May be used in conjunction with Servings Per Product Precision Code.

GDSN definition: The total number of servings contained in the package.
Business definition: The code indicating whether the specified Servings Per Product is approximate as shown on the product package.
Example: Image of a product showing servings per product declaration as "Approximate"
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the precision of the number of servings contained in the product as declared.  Used in conjunction with Servings Per Product.

GDSN definition: The total number of smallest units contained in the product. The smallest unit cannot be further divided without breaking or slicing the product. The smallest units may be uniform or may include a variety of items.
Business name: Number of Smallest Units For Food
Business definition: The total number of smallest units contained in the product. The smallest unit cannot be further divided without breaking or slicing the product. The smallest units may be uniform or may include a variety of items.
Example:
• A chicken that has been cut into 8 pieces, including breast, wings, drumsticks, thighs: 
Number of Smallest Units For Food = 8
• A package containing a minimum of 100 mixed variety hard candies: Number of Smallest Units For Food = 100.
• A 5 kilogram package of potatoes with a minimum of 30 individual potatoes in the package. Number of Smallest Units For Food = 30
Usage Statement:
Used by buyers for assortment planning.
Used by buyers to enable search and discovery by consumers in e-commerce and online stores.
Used by consumers to determine their product preference and enable comparative shopping decisions.

GDSN definition: A text description describing the range of servings/portions contained within a trade item. Some items may contain a variance in the number of units or a range, therefore the servings could also vary for the trade item. This attribute should only be used when there is a range of servings. If servings is an exact amount, this should not be used. An example of its use would be a bag of meatballs may contain 18-20 meatballs. If the serving size is 2 meatballs then the numberOfServingsRange would be 9-10 servings or portions.
Business name: Range of the Number of Servings
Business definition: The range of the number of servings in the product as shown on the product package.
Example:
Image of:
• chicken breast label with text "Serves 2 - 3"
• salad label with text "Serves 1 - 2"
• birthday cake label with text "Serves 6 - 8"
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the range of the number of servings per product.   Used by the seller to communicate the number of servings range only when the number of servings is variable.  When the number of servings is exact, use Servings Per Product.

GDSN definition: Textual instruction on how to prepare the product before serving.
Business definition: The instructions on how to prepare the product for consumption.
Example:
• How to prepare the turkey.
• Box of pasta or can of soup with preparation instructions.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer's customer service to answer questions about product preparation.
Used by the buyer and the consumer to prepare the product for consumption.

GDSN definition: A code specifying the technique used to make the product ready for consumption. For example: baking, boiling.
Business definition: The code specifying the method used to make the product ready for consumption.
Example:
Image of label with preparation instructions that correlate to each example:
• BAKE
• FREEZE
• READY_TO_EAT
Usage Statement: Used to provide one or more options to the consumer on how to prepare the product for consumption. Used by the buyer for search and discovery.

GDSN definition: Free text field for serving suggestion.
Business definition: A suggestion about the way the product may be served to enhance the consumer experience.
Example:
• A wine with attribute value: Best paired with fish and seafood.
• Image of a serving of turkey shown with gravy and parsley as a serving suggestion.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to enable search and discovery for the consumer.
May be used by the buyer for promotions and marketing.

GDSN definition: A description of any compulsory label information on the product. For example, the German additives regulation (ZzulV), for products such as meats and sausages, meat products, bread and bread products is needed for the serving counter.
Business definition: Describes legally required information about the product that is found on the product packaging.
Example:
• Fill level of the product may vary due to settling
• Do not refreeze
• Not suitable for use during pregnancy
Usage Statement: Used to notify buyers and consumers about legal information found on the product packaging.

GDSN definition: The description of features and benefits of the individual product, service, brand or seller.
Business definition: The description of features and benefits of the individual product, service, brand or seller.
Example: Show a bulleted list of features and benefits for a cosmetic product and for a digital camera.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the consumer key features and benefits of the product, intended to be shown as a bulleted list.

GDSN definition: Marketing message associated to the Trade item.
Business definition: The description of the product experience for the consumer.
Example:
Feeling tired, hard to get going in the morning? Start your day with Gina's Roast, an aromatic blend of the richest Colombian espresso beans. Gina's Roast is a sure way to start your day.
 
Our smooth, deep flavours will delight your palate, stimulate your senses, and awaken the tiger in you. Enjoy our brew with peace of mind, knowing that Gina’s Roast is sustainably harvested and fairly traded.  Not a tiger?  Gina’s Roast is available in decaf too!
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to digitally advertise and entice the consumer.

GDSN definition: A code indicating the degree of refinement, features, or capabilities for a trade item for example the quality grade of a ceramic tile.
Business definition: The description of the product's evaluation or ranking or class, such as quality, size, weight.
Example:
• UNECE Class 1 for apples
• USDA Grade AA for eggs (US)
• Grade A for eggs (EU)
• No. 1 for common lumber will have a few small, tight knots.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer the grade associated to the product.

Used by the buyer for verification and compliance.

Used by the buyer in assortment planning.

GDSN definition: Words or phrases that enables web search engines to find trade items on the internet for example Shampoo, Lather, Baby.
Business definition: The key words provided by the seller intended to help make the product discoverable by consumers using digital search engines.
Example:
A container of ice cream with key search words:
ice cream, lemon, brand name
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to optimise digital search engines, which may include online or in-store, for the consumer. Key words should be separated by commas with no spaces.

GDSN definition: An indicator whether or not the trade item is only offered during certain parts of the year or targeted to different seasons.
Business definition: The indicator that specifies whether the product is seasonal or offered during specific times of the year.
Example:
• Christmas or Easter chocolates with holiday specific packaging.
• Soccer World Cup bottle of soda.
• Halloween biscuits shaped like jack-o-lanterns.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to make procurement decisions. May be used by the buyer to update digital content.

GDSN definition: Identifies the target consumer age range for which a trade item has been designed.
Business definition: The description of the intended age or age range of the consumer.
Example:
• A toy intended for children ages 6 to 8 years.
• Baby food intended for ages 6 to 12 months.
• Baby clothes intended for specific age groups.
• Diapers targeted for specific age groups.
• Face cream for adults ages 40+.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to provide the target age range to the consumer. May be used by the buyer to guide shelf placement.

GDSN definition: Information on the constituent ingredient make-up of the product as specified for non-food items.
Business definition: The text used to describe the composition of the product that matches what appears on the label.
Example: Image showing an ingredient panel of such products as detergents, pain relievers, cosmetics.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the buyer and consumer of the ingredients.

GDSN definition: Determines whether the ingredient helps directly in achieving the objectives of the trade item.
Business definition: Indicates the presence of an active ingredient that achieves the desired results of using the product.
Example: Image showing an ingredient panel with the active ingredient circled.  Component of detergent that kills bacteria, mildew and fungi.  Analgesics with active ingredient of ibuprofen.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the buyer and consumer of active ingredients.

GDSN definition: The depth of the unit load, as measured according to the GS1 Package and Product Measurement Standard, including the shipping platform unless it is excluded according to the platformTypeCode chosen.
Business definition: A logistic unit not identified with a GTIN, the depth or length measurement (with its unit of measure) of the logistic unit according to the GS1 Package and Product Measurement Standard (https://www.gs1.org/standards/gs1-package-and-product-measurement-standard/current-standard).
Example: Image of logistic unit showing the directional measurement of depth
Usage Statement:
Used to fill or optimise truckloads when shipping in conjunction with Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Width and Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Height.

Used to determine the space in a storage facility in conjunction with Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Width and Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Height.

GDSN definition: The weight of both the unit load (content) and the plat-form upon which the goods are carried, if there is one.
Business definition: A logistic unit not identified with a GTIN, the total weight (with its unit of measure) of the product including the weight of all its packaging materials.
Example: Image of a bill of lading showing gross weight, or packing slip showing gross weight
Usage Statement: Used by the seller and the buyer to manage logistics, storage, safety limitations and truckload optimisation.

GDSN definition: The height of the unit load, as measured according to the GS1 Package and Product Measurement Standard, including the shipping platform unless it is excluded according to the platformTypeCode chosen.
Business definition: A logistic unit not identified with a GTIN, the vertical measurement (with its unit of measure) of the logistic unit according to the GS1 Package and Product Measurement Standard (https://www.gs1.org/standards/gs1-package-and-product-measurement-standard/current-standard).
Example: Image of a pallet of cases showing the directional measurement of height.
Usage Statement:
Used to fill or optimise truckloads when shipping in conjunction with Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Width and Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Depth/Length.

Used to determine the space in a storage facility in conjunction with Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Width and Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Depth/Length.

GDSN definition: The stacking factor of both the unit load (content) and the platform upon which the goods are carried, if there is one. A stacking factor deter-mines the maximum stacking for the product. Indicates the number of levels the product may be stacked.
Business definition: The maximum number of levels for a specific unit, not identified by a GTIN, that can exist in a stack without impacting the quality of the product. A value of 1 means that the item cannot be stacked.
Example:
• A Non-GTIN pallet which contains 40 Cases of paper towels which cannot be stacked over 4 pallets high, Stacking Factor for Non-GTIN Pallet is equal to 4.
• A Non-GTIN pallet which contains 120 Cases of water which cannot be stacked over 6 pallets high, Stacking Factor for Non-GTIN Pallet is equal to 6.
• A Non-GTIN pallet which contains 6 individually boxed TV sets that cannot be stacked on top of each other, Stacking Factor for Non-GTIN Pallet is equal to 1.
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer to determine how to store and/or transport the product, not identified by a GTIN, without impacting the quality of the product.

GDSN definition: The width of the unit load, as measured according to the GS1 Package and Product Measurement Standard, including the shipping platform unless it is excluded according to the platformTypeCode chosen.
Business definition: A logistic unit not identified with a GTIN, the horizontal measurement with the unit of measure of the logistic unit according to the GS1 Package and Product Measurement Standard (https://www.gs1.org/standards/gs1-package-and-product-measurement-standard/current-standard).
Example: Image of logistic unit showing the directional measurement of width.
Usage Statement:
Used to fill or optimise truckloads when shipping in conjunction with Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Height and Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Depth/Length.

Used to determine the space in a storage facility in conjunction with Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Height and Non-GTIN Logistic Unit Depth/Length.

GDSN definition: Nutrient Information is populated for those values which are relevant or required to be populated on the product label or label equivalent. All values not populated are not relevant or not required to be populated on the product label by local regulations.
Business definition: The indicator that confirms the relevant nutrient data provided for the product is complete.
Example: During the entry of data for a new or updated product, the nutrients may be suggested but at some point they are finalised. Once complete this tick box shows the nutrients are complete and confirmed.  Show a bottle of water with no nutrient information, but the indicator is true.
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to inform the buyer that the nutrient data is confirmed as complete.

GDSN definition: Free text field specifying the daily value intake base for on which the daily value intake per nutrient has been based. Example: “Based on a 2000 calorie diet.”
Business definition: The statement to the consumer describing the basis for calculating the percentage of nutrients that contribute to the recommended daily intake set by regulation.
Example: Image of food product highlighting the reference daily intake example: “Based on a 2000 calorie diet.”
Usage Statement: Used by the consumer to compare nutrients in a product to the recommended daily intake values.

GDSN definition: The basis amount that a nutrient is measured against when it is not serving size. For example, 120 gr in the case of 30 kj per 120 gr.
Business definition: The value, with its unit of measure, that forms the basis for referring to the nutrient content that appears on the product label.
Example: Image of a product's nutrient panel with the heading per "100 grams" and another showing per "10 oz".
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the basis value, with its defined unit of measure, used to calculate the amount of nutrients contained.

GDSN definition: The type of quantity contained for example measurement, serving size, or container.
Business definition: The code that qualifies if the nutritional information is based on a set measure or a serving size.
Example:
Image of a candy bar with the nutritional panel showing both the by measure and by serving. 

Show the code value BY_MEASURE and the Product Nutrient Basis Description from the nutrition panel "per 100g"

Then show the code value BY_SERVING and the Product Nutrient Basis Description from the nutriton panel "1 bar"
Usage Statement:
Used to inform the buyer and/or the consumer of the basis for the nutrient energy information.

Used by the buyer for menu planning, recipe creation, analysis.

Used in conjunction with Nutrient Basis.

GDSN definition: Code specifying the preparation state or type the nutrient information applies to, for example, unprepared, boiled, fried.
Business definition: The code indicating whether the product is unaltered versus a product that has been altered by consumer preparation, in conjunction with the nutritional panel.
Example:
• Cereal (unprepared) versus cereal with added milk (prepared).
• Sparkling lime water (unprepared).
• Macaroni (unprepared) versus Macaroni served with added cheese (prepared).
• Chicken boiled (prepared) or chicken fried (prepared).
Usage Statement: May be used by the consumer in conjunction with the nutritional panel to understand the differences in full nutritional values, prepared versus unprepared.

GDSN definition: Measurement value specifying the serving size or portion. In some markets due to regulation this information is used as the basis amount that a nutrient is measured against. Example: Per 30 grams. 1/2 cup, etc. Please refer to the target markets implementation guideline on how to populate this attribute.
Business definition: The value, with its unit of measure, that forms the basis for referring to the nutrient contents that appear on the product label.
Example: Image of a product's label with the heading "per serving".
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the basis value, with its defined unit of measure, used to calculate the amount of nutrients contained.

GDSN definition: A free text field specifying the serving size for which the nutrient information has been stated for example: per 1/3 cup (42 g).
Business definition: The description or additional information of the serving size for the product.
Example: Cereal with instruction for 1/2 cup cereal alone and 1/2 cup of cereal with 1/2 cup skim milk.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the recommended serving size and any additional information upon which the nutrients and energy are based on.

GDSN definition: The percentage of the recommended daily intake of a nutrient as recommended by authorities of the target market. Is expressed relative to the serving size and base daily value intake.
Business definition: The amount of the nutrient contained in the product as a percentage of the daily intake reference.
Example: Image of product where the nutrient and the percentage is highlighted.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of nutrient as a percentage of daily recommended intake.

GDSN definition: Code indicating whether the specified nutrient content is exact or approximate.
Business definition: The code indicating whether the specified nutrient content is approximate or less than as required by regulation and as shown on the product package.
Example: Image of a product showing nutrient declaration as "Approximate" or "Less than" declared.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the nutrient content value precision as declared.

GDSN definition: Code from the list of the INFOODS food component tag names.
Business definition: The code that represents a nutrient or energy element that is found in the product
Example: Show image of nutrition fact panel side by side with nutrient code for each line.
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer and the retailer of the nutrient or energy elements that are found in the product.

GDSN definition: Measurement value indicating the amount of nutrient contained in the product. Is expressed relative to the serving size.
Business definition: The value that indicates the amount of nutrient element or energy contained in the product per defined quantity with its unit of measure.
Example: Image showing a product with a nutrient fact panel showing it contains "27 grams of Fat Matter per 100 grams".
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer and the buyer of the nutrients and energy contained in a product and its unit of measure.

GDSN definition: Code indicating whether the specified nutrient content for the Daily Value Intake % is exact or approximate or less than etc. One should follow local regulatory guidelines when selecting a precision.
Business name: Daily Nutrient Value Percentage Precision Code
Business definition: The code indicating whether the specified nutrient content for the Daily Value Intake percentage is exact or approximate or less than as required by regulation.
Example: Image of a product showing greater than, less than or exact nutrient declaration
Usage Statement: Used to inform the consumer of the precision of the nutrient declaration.

GDSN definition: A taxonomic category ranking below a family and above a species and generally consisting of a group of species exhibiting similar characteristics. In taxonomic nomenclature the genus name is used, either alone or followed by a Latin adjective or epithet, to form the name of a species.
Business definition: The scientific name of a category of biological classification immediately above the Species.
Example:
Show in table with Genus, Species and Product Description.
• Malus (apple)
• Pelargonium (geranium)
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer and/or consumer to uniquely identify the type of product, particularly where the Product Description is not specific enough in order to comply with legal/ sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS)/ customs etc. requirements.

GDSN definition: A fundamental category of taxonomic classification, ranking below a genus and consisting of related organisms capable of interbreeding.   An organism belonging to such a category, represented in binomial nomenclature by an uncapitalized Latin adjective or noun following a capitalized genus name, as in Ananas comosus, the pineapple, and Equus caballus, the horse.
Business definition: The scientific name of a category of biological classification below the Genus.
Example:
Show in table with Genus, Species and Product Description.
• Malus domestica (apple)
• Pelargonium inquinans (scarlet geranium)
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer and/or consumer to uniquely identify the type of product, particularly where the Product Description is not specific enough in order to comply with legal/ sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS)/ customs etc. requirements.

Used in conjunction with Genus.

GDSN definition: A packaging feature thatfacilitates the usage of the product by the consumer.  Features do not affect the core composition of the packaging type nor modify its usage.
Business definition: The code that describes features about the packaging of the item.
Example:
Images of items or products with the following features:
• TWIST_OFF_CAP
• CHAMPAGNE_CORK_NATURAL
• HANDLE
• WICKER_OUTER_CONTAINER
• PULL_OFF_TAB
• BUNG_SEAL
• INTERNAL_DIVIDER
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer and consumer additional information related to packaging features that drive purchasing decisions.

GDSN definition: Indicates if the pallet in the prescribed pallet configuration is rented, exchangeable, against deposit or one way (not reusable).
Business definition: The code that describes the expected action to be taken with the pallet.
Example:
• Code 1 = No Exchange No Return
• Code 2 = Exchange Pallets
Usage Statement: Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer what to do with the pallet after it is received.

GDSN definition: Indicates whether the described despatch unit is delivered on a pallet/platform and on which type of platform. If the despatch unit is delivered on a platform, the platform type must be given here. The range of the platform types/codes is listed in code sets.
Business definition: The code that indicates the type of pallet that the unit load is delivered on.
Example:
• 11 - Image of a pallet with dimensions of 800 x 1200 mm (ISO 1 pallet, EUR pallet)
• 40 - Image of a pallet with dimensions of 1219 X 1016 mm (ISO 3 pallet)
• 33 - Image of cases on a dolly
• 9 - Image of a slip sheet
Usage Statement:
Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer the type and size of the pallet. Used by the buyer for handling, storing and moving.

The buyer determines the type of equipment suitable for transporting the pallet or dolly in the warehouse based on the pallet/dolly size and type.

GDSN definition: The dominant means used to transport, store, handle or display the trade item as defined by the data source. This packaging is not used to describe any manufacturing process. Data recipients can use this data for:• Space Planning• Data Accuracy (Tolerances)• Supply Chain processes• Recycling process (In combination with packaging materials)• Product buying/procurement decisions• Tax calculations/fees/duties calculation
Business definition: The code for the type of package or container of the product.
Example: Show multiple package code list values with images. Reuse existing content from GS1 Sweden or Netherlands.
Usage Statement:
Used in conjunction with the Packaging Material to provide information to the buyer on the type of product packaging for business process such as space planning, supply chain processes, recycling processes.

Used in conjunction with the Packaging Material to communicate packaging type to the consumer.

GDSN definition: The materials used for the packaging of the trade item for example glass or plastic.This material information can be used by data recipients for: o Tax calculations/fees/duties calculationo Carbon footprint calculations/estimations (resource optimisation)o to determine the material used.
Business definition: The code for the type of packaging material of the product.
Example:
• glass
• corrugated board
• metal/steel
• paper
• composite (brick)
Usage Statement: Used in conjunction with Packaging Material Quantity to provide information to the consumer and buyer on the type of material the product packaging is made of.  Also used for the calculation of taxes such as "Eco-packaging contribution".

GDSN definition: The quantity of the packaging material of the trade item. Can be weight, volume or surface, can vary by country.
Business definition: The amounts of the different materials that the packaging of the product contains.
Example: Example:  Show information about the amount of different materials (on some websites); Pull valid examples, could include valid units of measure such as a weight
Usage Statement: Used in conjunction with Packaging Material Code to provide information to the consumer about the amount of different materials that the product packaging contains that can be recycled, re-purposed, or disposed.  Also used for the calculation of taxes such as "Eco-packaging contribution".

GDSN definition: The monetary amount for the individual returnable package.
Business definition: The amount of deposit associated with a returnable package.
Example: Image of a bottle with the deposit amount circled.
Usage Statement:
Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer the amount of the deposit. 
Used by the buyer to communicate to the consumer (via receipt, website, mobile) the amount of the deposit.

GDSN definition: In some markets the deposit information is specified by a GTIN giving the type of returnable package on which a deposit is charged. Each deposit code is associated with an amount specified elsewhere. The enumeration list is maintained externally.
Business definition: The identifier for the package deposit.
Example: Image of a bottle of water with the GTIN and the deposit information circled.
Usage Statement:
Used by the buyer to:
• program automated return machines.
• include the deposit amount at Point Of Sale.
• reconcile invoicing.

GDSN definition: Indication whether the base trade item is batch or lot number requested by law, not batch or lot number requested by law but batch or lot number allocated, or not batch or lot number allocated. A batch or lot number is a manufacturer assigned code used to identify a trade item's trade item on batch or lot. Differs from Serial Number which is a manufacturer assigned code during the trade item on cycle to identify a unique trade item.
Business definition: The indicator specifying whether the item has a batch or lot number.
Example:
Image of:
•  bottle of acetaminophen with the batch or lot number circled.
• bottle of vitamins with the batch or lot number circled.
• carton of eggs with the lot number circled.
Usage Statement:
Used by the seller to communicate to the buyer products that are controlled for recalls.
Used by the buyer for inventory control processes.

GDSN definition: Trade item has returnable packaging. This is a yes/no (Boolean) where yes equals package can be returned. Attribute applies to returnable packaging with or without deposit.
Business definition: The indicator that specifies whether the product packaging is marked as returnable (with or without a deposit).
Example:
• Image of a glass bottle showing the mark for returnable package.
• Image of a flat of plants where the flat is marked returnable.
• Image of a crate for fresh foods where the crate is marked returnable.
Usage Statement:
Used to provide the consumer and the buyer with information on how to handle the product packaging post-consumption.
Not to be used for accreditation.

GDSN definition: Indication of whether there is a retail price physically on or attached to the trade item packaging of the trade item by the manufacturer or information provider.
Business name: Retail Price is Marked on the Product Indicator
Business definition: The indicator used to inform the buyer that there is a retail price on the product.
Example:
• books
• magazines
• greeting cards
• potato chips, when pre-priced
Usage Statement: Used by the buyer for price management.

GDSN definition: The code representing a symbol or marking on the product and/or product package defined by a third party. This does not include regulatory markings.
Business name: Third Party Accreditation Symbol on Product Package Code
Business definition: The code representing a symbol or marking on the product and/or product package defined by a third party. This does not include regulatory markings.
Example:
Image showing:
• UTZ certified for cacao
• FSC certified for sustainable wood for paper products
Usage Statement: Used to communicate the global, national and local accreditation to the buyer and consumer. (See the GDSN Trade Item Implementation Guide Packaging Label Guide: https://www.gs1.org/standards/gdsn/trade_implementation_guide)

GDSN definition: Warning information is additional information that outlines special requirements, warning and caution information printed on the package.
Business definition: The information provided to the consumer about warnings or dangers associated with the product.
Example:
• Warning choking hazard
• Warning about consumption of product
• Warning about the packaging of the product
• Dangers associated with electrical appliances and water
